text:
[Cites 
11
, Cited by 
0
]

Delhi High Court - Orders

Darshan Singh vs State Of Nct Of Delhi on 19 September, 2025

Author: 
Neena Bansal Krishna

Bench: 
Neena Bansal Krishna

 $~7
 * IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
 + BAIL APPLN. 2880/2025
 DARSHAN SINGH .....Petitioner
 Through: Mr. Varun Deswal, Mr. Siddhartha S.
 Yadav, Mr. Danish Khan, Mr. Ayush
 Kumar Singh and Ms. Kashish Ahuja,
 Advocates
 versus
 STATE OF NCT OF DELHI .....Respondent
 Through: Mr. Utkarsh, APP for the State
 Mr. Nikhil and Mr. Punit, Advocates
 for Complainant

 CORAM:
 HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE NEENA BANSAL KRISHNA
 ORDER

 % 19.09.2025

 1. First Bail Application under Section 483 of the Bharatiya Nagarik
 Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 has been filed on behalf of the Applicant/Darshan
 Singh for grant of Anticipatory Bail in FIR No. 0705/2024 under 
Section
 498A
/
406
/
34
 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 and 
Section 85
/
316
/
3(5)
 of the
 Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, dated03.12.2024, registered at Police Station
 Palam Village, District South-West.

 2. It is submitted that the Applicant is a law-abiding citizenand has clean
 antecedents and has been wrongly and falsely implicated in the present case
 being the father of the main accused Pankaj Lamba whowas the husband of
 the Complainant's daughter.

 3. It is submitted that Pankaj Lamba (son of the Applicant) and Harshita
 Barela (daughter of the Complainant) got married on 22.03.2024 according to

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47
 Hindu rights and ceremonies, in an arranged marriage. It was alleged by the
 Complainant that the co-accused and his family, had subjected the
 Complainant's daughter and her family to cruelty and harassment on account
 of dowry demand, even prior to the solemnization of their marriage.

 4. After the marriage, the co-accused Pankaj Lamba (husband) went to
 United Kingdom, while the Complainant's daughter moved into her
 matrimonial home in Dharoli. She was allegedly subjected to harassment and
 cruelty, which led her to leave the matrimonial home and stay at her parental
 house. She later moved to Corby City, United Kingdom, on 30.04.2024,
 where the cruelty persisted until her death on 14.11.2024.

 5. It was alleged by the Complainant, father of the deceased that his
 daughter was subjected to cruelty by the Applicant and his family even while
 she was in UK and that the same persisted during the subsistence of the
 marriage till the date of thedeath of his daughter on 14.11.2024, about which
 the Complainant was informed on 15.11.2024.On his Complaint, FIR under
 
Sections 498A
/
406
/
34
 IPC was registered and thereafter, 
Section 304B
 was
 added.

 6. Learned Senior Counsel for the Applicant has submitted that the
 Applicant is in judicial custody since 14.03.2025. The prosecution has
 wrongly added 
Section 304B
 as at the relevant time, the Applicant had no
 nexus with the Complainant's daughter as she was residing in UK and it is
 wrongly alleged that she was subject to any kind of cruelty orharassment for
 or in relation to the dowry demand by the Applicant.

 7. It is further submitted that the learned Sessions' Court has erroneously
 dismissed Applicant's Bail Application vide Order dated 01.04.2025 and did
 not consider that the FIR does not disclose any allegation of cruelty or

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47
 harassment "soon before death" which resulted in the dowry death of the
 deceased. the Applicant has thus, sought bail.

 8. It is also submitted that this Court vide Order dated 04.04.2025 and
 Order dated 08.04.2025 has granted interim protection tosimilarly placed
 co-accused persons namely Satinder Kumar, brother-in-law of the Applicant
 and Lalita, sister of the Applicant. Also, vide Order dated 09.04.2025, Uma
 Lamba, daughter of the Applicant has alsobeen granted anticipatory bail.

 
9. Reliance has been placed on 
Pepsi Foods Ltd. vs. Special Judicial
 Magistrate
 (1998) 5 SCC 749 to submit that at the time of consideration of
 grant of bail, the Court has to take a prima facie viewof whether the offence
 has been made out or not.

 
10. Reliance has been placed on the case of 
Manohar Lal vs. State of
 Haryana
, (2014) 9 SCC 645 wherein the Apex Court held that "Facts must
 show existence of proximate live link between the effect of cruelty based on
 dowry demand and death of victim".

 
11. Reliance has also been placed 
Balwant Singh and Anr. vs. State of
 Punjab
, (2004) 7 SCC 724, the Apex Court held that since one of the
 ingredients of the offence under 
Section 304B
 IPC is that cruelty should have
 been meted out to the deceased soon before her death; it is for the prosecution
 to establish affirmatively that the victim was subjected tocruelty and
 harassment based on dowry demand soon before her death.

 12. The alleged dowry death took place in UK and that the Applicant being
 here in India had no knowledge of what transpiredbetween the deceased and
 the main Accused (Pankaj Lamba).

 13. The Chargesheet in the instant matter has already been filed with
 investigation having been completed and since Applicant has already been in

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47
 custody for over 4 months now which makes good the fact that any essential
 information would have been gathered by the respondents till now and no
 further interrogation is warranted. Thus, further custody of the Applicant is
 notwarranted.

 
14. It is well settled that gravity alone cannot be decisive ground to deny
 bail, rather competing factors are required to be balanced by the court while
 exercising its discretion. Reliance has been placed on 
Sanjay Chandra versus
 Central Bureau of Investigation
, (2012)1 SCC 49 and Sunder Singh Bhati Vs.
 The State Bail Application No. 3750/2021.

 15. Furthermore, the grant of Bail is a norm and refusal thereof is exception
 and the Courts should exercise the discretion of Bail judicially and the Bail
 should not be denied to an accused only as a punishment.

 16. It is submitted that the Applicant is 60 years old and has clean
 antecedents. He undertakes that he will not flee from justice if he isadmitted
 to Bail and is ready and willing to co-operate with administrationof justice.
 He is not a flight risk as his wife and 21-year-old daughter are also a
 permanent resident of Dharoli, Jhajjar, Haryana and thus, has deep roots in
 society. Further, since the investigation in the present matter has already been
 concluded with Chargesheet having been filed, thereare no chances of
 Applicant tampering with evidence.

 17. Thus, it is prayed that Bail be granted to the Applicant.

 18. Status Report has been filed on behalf the State and the same is taken
 on record.

 19. In the Status Report, it is stated that the Complainant in his complaint
 has mentioned that his daughter had many times complained that her husband
 and in-laws are not good people and they may kill her for want of money. It is

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47
 also mentioned that an amount of Rs.15,00,000/- was given to the family of
 Pankaj Lamba for visa of UK in September, 2024. The deceased filed a
 Domestic Violence Complaint against her husband, Mr. Pankaj Lamba, for
 beating and dowry demands.

 20. It was further stated by the Complainant that on 10.11.2024 at 10:00
 p.m., his daughter made a video call to him wherein she was continuously
 crying and was saying that she be taken away or her husband may kill her.
 Sister-in-law,Ms. Uma also used to threaten her on phone from India.

 21. The Statement of the parents of the deceased, namely, Smt. Sudesh and
 Complainant, Mr. Satbir Singh, were recorded by the SDM on 30.11.2024
 wherein they sated that dowry demands of huge cash and jewellery, was being
 made by the husband and his relatives from the deceased since the date of her
 marriage and she was being regularly harassed and tortured on this account.
 She was also threatened that in casethe demands were not fulfilled, she would
 have to bear the consequences.

 22. The Bail Application is opposed on the grounds that there were specific
 allegations against the Applicant for demand of dowry and harassment. The
 investigation is at an initial stage and there is an apprehension of tampering
 with the evidence and this Application deservesto be dismissed.
 Submissions heard and record perused.

 23. The allegation against the Applicant/father-in-law is that at the time
 marriage of deceased was fixed with his son, demand of Rs.5,00,000/- was
 made and the deceased was harassed for not bringing thismoney even after
 the marriage. The fact remains that marriage between Applicant's son/Pankaj
 Lamba with the deceased was solemnized on 22.03.2024.

 24. The deceased had joined her husband in UK on 30.04.2024 where she

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47
 took up a job and the unfortunate incident of her demise on 14.11.2024 also
 took place in UK. It is to be noted that the deceased had stayed at her
 matrimonial house only for about 10-15 days, after which she moved to her
 Parental home and from there she went to the UK. The alleged dowry death
 occurred in the UK, while the Applicant was here in India and as such no
 specific role as been ascribed to the Applicant. The Chargesheet stands filed
 and there are a total 21 witnesses who are to be examined.

 25. In the totality of circumstances, without going into the merits of the
 case, the Applicant is admitted to bail on his furnishing Bail bond in the sum
 of Rs.25,000/- with one Surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of
 theTrial Court, subject to the undertaking that:-

 I. The Petitioner shall not misuse the liberty of bail granted to
 him;

 II. The Petitioner shall not tamper with any evidence, oral or
 documentary during the trial;

 III. The Petitioner shall give his cell phone number to
 theInvestigating Officer and keep it operational; and
 IV. The Petitioner shall appear before the Trial Court on every date
 of hearing.

 26. With aforesaid, the present Bail Application is accordingly disposedof.

 NEENA BANSAL KRISHNA, J.

 SEPTEMBER 19, 2025
 va

This is a digitally signed order.

The authenticity of the order can be re-verified from Delhi High Court Order Portal by scanning the QR code shown above.
The Order is downloaded from the DHC Server on 24/09/2025 at 21:40:47

matched_landmarks.full_citation: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273
matched_landmarks.legal_principle: Mandatory arrest not required for offences punishable less than 7 years

suggested_precedents.full_citation: Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab, (1980) 2 SCC 684
suggested_precedents.legal_principle: Death penalty - rarest of rare doctrine
